question_details.title: Will the following companies be added to the S&P 500 before 2026? (ARES)
question_details.description:
The [S\&P 500 Index](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S%26P_500) is a stock market index that measures the stock performance of 500 large companies listed on stock exchanges in the United States. The index is maintained by [S\&P Dow Jones Indices](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S%26P_Dow_Jones_Indices), and inclusion decisions are based on factors such as market capitalization, liquidity, financial viability, and sector representation. Current index constituents can be viewed [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_S%26P_500_companies#S\&P_500_component_stocks).

S\&P 500 membership is valued by corporations because it indicates success and boosts brand awareness.

To join S\&P 500 a company must fulfill the following requirements:

* It must have a market capitalization of at least \$20.5 billion.
* It must be domiciled in the U.S.
* It must be a corporation whose shares are listed on an exchange, such as the New York Stock Exchange, the Nasdaq system, or one of the CBOE exchanges.
* It can not be a limited partnership, master limited partnership, closed-end fund, limited liability company, special purpose acquisition company, or SPAC.

Four possible candidates to be added to the S\&P 500 in over the following months are:

* [ARES (Ares Management Corporation)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ares_Management): A global alternative investment firm specializing in credit, private equity, real estate, and infrastructure assets.
* [MSTR (MicroStrategy Incorporated)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MicroStrategy): A business analytics company known for significant investments in Bitcoin as part of its corporate treasury strategy.
* [APP (AppLovin Corporation)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AppLovin): A mobile technology company providing software solutions for mobile app monetization, marketing automation, and in-app advertising optimization.
* [CVNA (Carvana Co.)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carvana): An e-commerce platform for buying and selling used vehicles online, featuring direct-to-consumer delivery and a technology-driven customer experience.

question_details.resolution_criteria:
This question is a subquestion of a group question. This subquestion specifically targets the option 'ARES'. The resolution criteria for the parent question is below. 

Each subquestion will resolve as **Yes** if the corresponding company is announced to be officially added to the S\&P 500 Index before January 1, 2026, according to [S\&P Dow Jones Indices](https://www.spglobal.com/).
question_details.fine_print:
* Subquestions will resolve based on official announcements from S\&P Dow Jones Indices that a company will be added. The actual inclusion of the company to the index is not required for resolution.
* Potential retractions or cancellations of an inclusion announcement will not affect the resolution of subquestions.

**S&P 500's rejection of the company formerly called MicroStrategy may stop the crypto-acquisition frenzy: JPMorgan**
JPMorgan strategists, led by Nikolaos Panigirtzoglou, argue that the S&P 500’s decision to exclude the company formerly known as MicroStrategy—now Strategy MSTR—signals a broader concern about corporate treasury investments in cryptocurrency. The company meets the size and other key criteria for inclusion, yet its market capitalization is largely derived from bitcoin holdings rather than its underlying information‑technology business. The strategists claim the exclusion could limit the influx of crypto assets into investor portfolios and may prompt other index providers to reconsider including similar corporate crypto treasuries. They also note that the Nasdaq has begun requiring shareholder approval for companies that use crypto assets to fund new share issuances. The article suggests that investors and index providers might shift their focus toward crypto firms with real operating businesses, such as exchanges or miners, rather than corporate treasuries. 'This is signaling that the committee, which can apply discretion in its index inclusion decisions, is concerned about including in the S&P 500 index companies such as MicroStrategy that are effectively bitcoin funds,' the strategists said.

**S&P 500 changes are due out soon - and this could be a big update**
The S&P 500 index committee is expected to announce a quarterly rebalance after Friday’s close, with changes taking effect two weeks later.  The most recent quarter saw no updates, prompting speculation that the next reshuffle—typically the largest because it incorporates annual float‑factor adjustments—might bring new members.  Melissa Roberts, a managing director at Stephens, noted that the "third‑quarter reshuffle is typically the largest rebalance because it includes annual constituent float‑factor changes," and that "S&P Dow Jones Indices historically took advantage of the liquidity opportunity to make more discretionary changes than in other quarters."  To qualify for inclusion, a U.S.‑domiciled company must have a market capitalization of at least $22.7 billion, a float market capitalization of at least $10.25 billion, and demonstrate financial viability by being profitable on a GAAP basis in the most recent quarter and over the past four quarters.  Current candidates include AppLovin Corp. (APP), Reddit Inc. (RDDT), Pinterest Inc. (PINS), Robinhood Markets Inc. (HOOD), Sofi Technologies Inc. (SOFI) and Carvana Co. (CVNA).  AppLovin, with a $164 billion market cap, is the largest eligible firm, while Strategy Inc. (MSTR), formerly MicroStrategy, has newly cleared the financial‑viability hurdle. summary: Forecasters broadly agree that Ares Management (ARES) is a highly eligible and frequently cited candidate for S&P 500 inclusion before 2026, meeting all objective requirements such as market capitalization, liquidity, profitability, corporate structure, and sector fit. Key factors boosting ARES’s probability are the S&P 500’s current underweighting of financials (especially alternative asset managers) and consistent mentions by analysts and news sources as a leading contender in upcoming rebalances. Several forecasters note that sector representation pressures and passive fund flows support the case for ARES. However, most experts also highlight substantial uncertainty due to the S&P 500 committee’s discretionary and sometimes unpredictable decision-making, citing recent high-profile examples (such as MicroStrategy) where technical eligibility did not guarantee inclusion. The competition for a limited number of available slots is stiff, with other prominent candidates (such as AppLovin, Robinhood, Carvana, and Cheniere) vying for inclusion, and the major September rebalance has already passed without ARES being selected. Most experts estimate the remaining opportunities will occur in the December rebalance or in response to unplanned constituent departures. Final probability estimates vary: the majority cluster between 35% and 75%, with the modal range from 40% to 72%, centering around 60-65% among finance and accounting experts, but somewhat lower (22-45%) among those emphasizing recent committee discretion, competition, or historical base rates post-major rebalance. Across all perspectives, ARES is seen as an above-base-rate candidate but far from a certainty, with odds that are meaningfully better than random, yet still reflecting the constraints of timing, discretion, and competition.
